level1-simple.title: Level 1: Simple Drawdown
level1-simple.description: Basic scenario: $120k savings, $3k/month expenses, 2% growth. See how long money lasts with no income.

metadata.title: Level 1: Simple Asset Drawdown
metadata.notes: Sarah, 60, has $120,000 in savings earning 2% annually. She needs $3,000/month for living expenses. No other income sources. How long will her money last?

level2-income.title: Level 2: Adding Social Security
level2-income.description: Same scenario but Social Security starts in month 12. Watch the dramatic sustainability improvement!

metadata.title: Level 2: Impact of Social Security Income
metadata.notes: Same Sarah, but Social Security of $1,800/month begins in month 12 (year 1). This reduces her monthly shortfall from $3,000 to just $1,200. See how income timing dramatically affects sustainability.

level3-multiple.title: Level 3: Multiple Assets & Withdrawal Priority
level3-multiple.description: Bob has low-yield savings and high-yield investments. Strategic withdrawal order preserves growth longer.

metadata.title: Level 3: Strategic Asset Withdrawal Priority
metadata.notes: Bob, 62, has $50k in savings (1.5% growth) and $200k investments (6% growth). He spends savings first to preserve higher-growth assets longer. Social Security starts in month 24. Compare this strategy to spending investments first.

ss-claim-62.title: Social Security: Early Claiming at 62
ss-claim-62.description: Maria claims at 62 for immediate income but reduced monthly benefit. Compare with delayed claiming strategies.

metadata.title: SS Strategy A: Early Claiming at Age 62
metadata.notes: Maria, 60, retires with $650k total assets. She claims Social Security early at 62 (month 24) receiving $2,100/month (75% of full benefit). This provides immediate cash flow but permanent benefit reduction. Monthly shortfall: $4,400 after SS starts.

ss-claim-67.title: Social Security: Full Retirement Age (67)
ss-claim-67.description: Maria waits for full benefit: higher monthly amount but more early asset depletion. Compare the trade-offs.

metadata.title: SS Strategy B: Full Retirement Age Claiming (67)
metadata.notes: Same Maria waits until full retirement age (month 84) to claim $2,800/month (100% benefit). Higher monthly amount but requires 7 years of full asset drawdown ($6,500/month). Monthly shortfall: $3,700 after SS starts.

ssdi-approved.title: SSDI Success Story
ssdi-approved.description: Tom gets SSDI approval: immediate full retirement benefit at 58. This is the best-case financial scenario.

metadata.title: SSDI Approved: The Financial Game-Changer
metadata.notes: Tom, 58, successfully gets SSDI approval and receives his full retirement benefit ($2,600/month) immediately - 9 years early! This converts to regular Social Security at 67. With $225k in assets and $5,200 monthly expenses, his shortfall drops to just $2,600/month.

default.title: Balanced Portfolio Example
default.description: Multi-account retirement scenario with strategic withdrawal order and Social Security timing.

metadata.title: Balanced Retirement Portfolio Strategy
metadata.notes: Balanced scenario with 4 account types: Emergency savings (3.75%), Growth investments (6%), Traditional IRA (6%), and Roth IRA (6%). Social Security starts at month 24. Withdrawal priority preserves tax-advantaged accounts longest.
